720802f.text:
Lafayette Street, West Side, between E.4th Street and Astor Place, showing the "Colonnade Row," where John Jacob Astor
and other prominent Americans have resided.
About 1895
Langwill,
Credit line imperative.
NEG.: 2816

720803f.text:
Lafayette Street (Elm Street), north from but not including East 4th, to and including East 8th Streets (where it terminates), showing construction work in progress on the Interborough Rapid Transit Co. (I.R.T.) Subway. In the background is shown the Germania Theatre, adjoining the N.W. corner of Fourth Ave. It was later razed and on its site was erected (between 1902 and 1905) the 14-story main building of the John Wanamaker Department Store. On the right are visible the lower floors of the Astor Library, now (1937)
the home of the Hebrew Immigration Aid Society ('Hias").
April 1, 1901.
Board of Transportation Photograph.
William B. Parsons Collection.

720801f-a.text:
Lafayette Street, west side, north from a point above E. 4th Street, to Astor Place (right), showing prominently the row of distinctive structures known ss "Colonnade Row". Note the "Churchman" in the north building. At the right margin appears a glimpse of the Wannamaker (formerly A. T. Stewart)
Department Store building.
1911
H. N. Tiemann, photo
Gift of Urbrock Collection

720798f-b.text:
(1)
428-434 and 436-44O Lafayette Street, west side, between East 4th Street and Astor Place. No. 428-434 is known as the "Colonnade Buildings." It is a part of the row of houses which was known as Colonnade Row, where John Jacob Astor and other prominent merchants lived in the 1870's. The building shown in this view is the northern half of the Row and its northernmost section was for many years occupied by the Churchman, the leading paper of the Protestant Episcopal Church. It was then known as 47 Lafayette Place and was the centre of New York's intellectual supremacy. For a number of years the building has been occupied by the Conte Restaurant and is still there to date (1937).
September 26, 1929.
P. L. Sperr.
(2)
The same, showing an exclusive view of the Colonnade Buildings.
September 26, 1929.
P. L. Sperr.
No. 432 Lafavette Street was the home of Julia Gardner, bride of President Tyler.

720797f.text:
428-34 Lafayette Street, west side, between East 4th Street and Astor Place, showing the distinctive row of houses known as the "Colonnade". This was formerly called "La Crange Terrace", in honor of General Lafayette's home. They were erected in 1827 snd for a time were the home of Washington Irving and John Jacob Astor. The Churchman, the leading paper of the Protestant Episcopal Church was published here at the time when this was the center of New Yorks intellectual supremacy, at what was then No. 47 Lafayette Place. For a number of years this building has been occupied by the Conte
Restaurant.
1938-9
Works Progress Authority  neg #638
Federal Writers Project

720800f-a.text:
Lafayette Street, at the North West corner of East 4th Street. This place later became the printing house of the C.J.O'Brien Company.
About 1920
M.B.R.
